benchmark_details.name: ViLBias
benchmark_details.overview: ViLBias is a VQA-style benchmark and framework for detecting and reasoning about bias in multimodal news, comprising 40,945 text-image pairs from diverse outlets, each annotated with a bias label and concise rationale using a hybrid LLM-as-annotator pipeline.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: The main goal is to assess the ability of language models, specifically vision-language models (VLMs), to detect and reason about media bias.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The dataset coverage skews towards English-language and Western media, limiting cross-cultural generalizability.

data.source: 40,945 text-image pairs collected from diverse news sources including CNN, BBC, and The New York Times.
data.annotation: Combines LLM-based automated labeling with extensive human review for quality assurance.

methodology.calculation: Metrics are calculated using standard evaluation protocols across multiple model evaluations.
methodology.interpretation: Higher accuracy indicates better bias detection, while reasoning quality is assessed by faithfulness to the evidence.
methodology.baseline_results: RoBERTa+CLIP achieved F1 of 82.9% and accuracy of 83.6%.
methodology.validation: 5-fold cross-validation and human review ensure reliability of annotations.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: The dataset lacks comprehensive coverage of diverse demographic groups.
harm: Reinforcement of existing societal biases through biased media representations
